betterquesting:10.desc:8: Welcome to GTOW! Thanks for choosing to play this pack, starting off is easy! Just grab a bit of wood and you'll be doing great!
Flint is a key material in early crafting, and one of the first durable ingredients to make tools out of. It can be crafted through 3 gravel as well. Go grab some flint!

To get into crafting you'll need some bark, which you can get through breaking wood blocks with a knife, to get a knife you'll need some flint and a stick, if you craft the gregtech knife, however, you can recraft it into a Roots one.

With your newfound knife you can start knapping up wood to get bark! Right click on some vanilla wood to get that respective bark.

§cTHIS ONLY WORKS ON VANILLA BARK! §fChanges are pending for this.

Do you have too many books? Of course you do! The Akashic Tome solves that issue by consolidating all mod guidebooks you obtain into one central book, including this here questbook! Hopefully the documentation in this is enough, but§ §f in case we are too dumb and don't put in enough information you always have the books to look back on.
Finally you can obtain a crafting table, it's as simple as two bark and two logs. At last 3x3 stations it only took- what 3 minutes?

Rustic is a pretty neat mod

In order to progress in food quests and in agriculture you need to set up basic alchemy with rustic. You need an alchemic condensor with two alchemic retorts, some sort of fuel, water, and glass bottles for any recipe. You can also use these to make potions with Rustic crops, which can be helpful and powerful.
Because of your lack of tools, you don't have much access to stone yet, luckily you can still get fragments of stone by breaking gravel open with your knife.

The Roots Pestle and Mortar is the first major step in order to get blank patterns. In order to use this item you have to place the mortar on the ground and put the respective ingredients in, then you can mix it together. Later you will get a way better mortar, but that's not right now.
Wood Pulp is gotten by pulverizing a log in a mortar and pestle. Later you can get two pulp per piece, but right now it's one to one
The base for tool crafting is now available, enjoy your freedom

Roots and Rustic are simultaneously the first magic mods you can get into. While Rustic is more of a primitive tech mod, Roots is the major magic enabler at the start of the pack. Both have a heavy focus on nature so you'll need to get your green thumb on.

The quest here is to make a pyre, this is normally meant to be lit with a flint and steel, but without steel you'll need a different type of firestarter, like a match. While you can't light a Pyre with a match, lighting the ground next to it will cause the Pyre to begin doing rituals.

Go to GregTech jail

The soft hammer is the first real GregTech tool you can make, it can be crafted out of 6 planks and a stick in a regular hammer formation. This is required for basic technology making.

With your newfound soft hammer you can make a bed, and are now able to skip those horrible, horrible nights.

Of note, the hammer in the recipe is §l§cNOT §fconsumed on use. It only takes damage, and this is true of most recipes.

No, not quite yet.

At this current point you do not have the ability to make chests, sorry about that. Luckily for you, completing this quest will give you some chests in case your inventory is filled. All it takes is some wood.

Combining all of your current tools and gizmos together should allow you to make the 4 tinkers work stations. This pack unifies all of the part builders and stencil tables into one, so no need to worry about having the correct type of wood.
With your tools it is now very easy to gather a lot of these basic materials, like sand and clay. You'll need these materials to make better blocks for protection and for primitive technology.
Flint tools are the easiest ones to make as of yet, and the most durable. This quest wants you to get a flint axe, pickaxe, and shovel.
A brick form is required for brick making, obviously. You'll need just about every brick you can make with this, so you'll be using it a lot.
Cobblestone is a great and sturdy building material, as well as an important item in crafting. Get your pickaxe to work now!
Hammers are an important tool in most GregTech crafting, but because you don't have metals and cannot make a furnace, your first hammer will be made out of cobblestone.

Grout is a handy compound made of clay, sand, and gravel. You'll need it specifically for both the Seared Furnace (First proper furnace in the pack) and the Smeltery (First way of obtaining Iron). You'll end up needing a lot of it, almost 2 stacks for the furnace alone.

To make grout you need to throw one sand, one gravel, and one clay dust into a body of water and it will consume the water, because of the fact that there is finite water in the pack you need to do this one at a time. Later, once you have the seared furnace, you can make grout more easily and without water, but for now you are limited to this.

To get unfired seared bricks is easy, however. You just stamp grout through a wooden brick form and you get it out. The wonders of technology!

There are many varieties of seeds in the world, even disregarding the pam's ones. The main ones to use early on are Actually Additions crops and Roots crops, as well as some vanilla ones.

Of note is that wildroot is gotten by either breaking tall grass or by cutting regular grass with your knife.
By burning an unfired seared brick in a fire to can make fired seared bricks! You can also throw in more than one at a time to make multiple.

betterquesting:10.name:8: Light The Fire Up In The Night
betterquesting:10.desc:8: Your first way of starting fire is with a match, fire is a very handy resource for cooking up objects and items, though it may be too fast and hot to make some items, like bricks. But the use of fire will definitely advance your civilization past the stone age.

Glass is a tricky material to get.

In order to make glass you have to burn glassy sand, which itself is a compound of glass dust and sand, with glass dust being a compound of sand dust and flint dust. While it's nothing expensive, it's quite a process.

For fluid collection, we'll need to start off with clay. It is a very primitive way of transporting fluids and breaks after placing down lava, but it will work for now. You get it by burning an unfired clay bucket into a fire for a few seconds. Don't worry, you won't loose the clay bucket.

Combining all of the materials at your disposal you should now be able to make a seared furnace. A proper improvement over firing or drying your items. Unfortunately, getting all the required ingredients wont be easy.

For the full multiblock you'll end up needing exactly 60 seared bricks, or just under a stack of bricks. All the seared bricks go into the components you see, 8 seared brick blocks arranged almost like a capped donut (a rough schematic is at the bottom of this text), a seared furnace controller, and a seared tank. You also need lava to power the furnace, and finding that could be an issue in and of itself. If you can't find lava for the life of you, you can use creosote oil just as well.

This quest also gives you a free lava florb, which basically acts as a throwable lava source. You can use this to power the furnace as well, but you're going to need a reliable source of lava at some point.

Minimum Furnace:

Top Layer

(air)       (air)        (air)
(air) (seared brick) (air)
(air)       (air)        (air)

Mid Layer

(seared brick) (seared brick) (seared brick)
(seared brick)        (air)       (seared brick)
(seared brick) (furnace cont.) (seared tank)

Bottom Layer

(air)       (air)        (air)
(air) (seared brick) (air)
(air)       (air)        (air)

Do you love charcoal? Of course you do! That's why you need to make yourself a coke oven. No seriously make it.

A coke oven provides two essential resources, charcoal and creosote (also coal coke, but you can choose whichever burnable product you want). Charcoal or Coal Coke acts as an effective fuel in boilers, while creosote is required for treated wood and also can be used in later boilers and as a fuel. In total this takes 120 coke clay.

Despite the JEI information saying otherwise, you don't need a coke oven hatch for it to work, which is why it is not required for this quest.
The Coke Oven Hatch acts as an output for the coke oven. If you place a tank behind it, the oven automatically outputes creosote into it. How awesome!
If you play on a new update of this pack, chances are that the questbook has changed. Completing this quest will reload the questbook, meaning you get all the new quests!

This pack has a fully customized ore generation and world generation system. This means that there is a lot of things you're going to need to know.

Firstly, caves do not generate. Ravines and other underground structures do generate, but there are no caves in this world. There are also no non-Gregtech ores, and all of those ores generate in large veins underground. These veins are massive and filled with tons of ores depending on the type of vein. Vein information can be found in JEI. (Note that the stone of each ore is interchangeable, basalt cassiterite is the same as granite cassiterite) These large veins generate on a consistent map of veins.

To find any one of these veins you need to find your coordinate of the chunk you are in (That is, your placement on the minecraft chunk grid, found by opening the F3 menu and looking at the second set of numbers in the Chunk listing, which is two below your XYZ coordinates) and only focus on the first and last values, we do not care about the middle one. Secondly, disregard any negative signs, if both of those values are some sort of multiple of 3 plus 1, there is an ore vein there. 

Additionally, the harvest levels of the minerals are customized. Which means you can't get some materials before getting a certain tier of pickaxe. This is used to limit progression, luckily all the mining heads needed will be listed off in the questbook, so it should be fine *probably*. The harvest level of a block indicates the first material a pickaxe head can be made out of that mines at that level.

With your flint pickaxe you can really only mine a few basic ores, copper being one of them. The main places you will find copper this early on is in Bornite and Chalcopyrite veins. For the chalcopyrite vein you can mine both the copper and chacopyrite ore, while with the bornite vein you can only mine the Chalcolite and Copper ore. Regardless, get some copper

With your flint pickaxe you can really only mine a few basic ores, tin being one of them. The main places you will find tin this early on is in Cassiterite Sand and Magnetite veins. For the Cassiterite sand vein you can mine everything in it, while with the Magnetite vein you can only mine the tin ore. Of note, the cassiterite sand smelts into tin as well.

The tinker's smeltery is the way to get into further metallurgy. Most importantly it can blend together alloys, which is what is required in order to get iron. It can also smelt them out into certain casts.

This quest shows the resources for the smallest possible smeltery but you are most certainly going to want something a bit bigger. This is just the minimum amount of material required to progress.

You can find and mine coal veins now, and while the coal itself is already pretty nice to have, coal coke is a way cooler material that burns for twice as long! All you need to do is put it through a coke oven.

Bronze is an alloy of 3 copper and 1 tin. You cannot make a dust blend for this alloy, so you have to alloy those two together in the smeltery. This alloy will be the basis for all of your steam machines, and is how to get higher tier metals.

You do not have access to gold or aluminium, which means you do not have any form of reusable cast, unless you want to smelt up the ingot cast each time. For now, the only casts you can use are out of clay. In my unending generousity, I will gift you some blank casts for this quest.
Just your regular, everyday, bricks. Nothing odd here.

betterquesting:10.name:8: The Dawn Of The Steam Age
betterquesting:10.desc:8:
Steam power is the first form of machinery you can get, and now you can finally make it.

None of the materials are especially much to get, and can all be gotten fairly easily, this steam machine runs off of burnable fuels, like coal, to heat up water. You must have a constant supply of water otherwise it will blow up. No one wants an explosion, do we?

1:10.command:8:
#Script Comment
say @s Has entered the Steam Age!

betterquesting:10.desc:8: Brick blocks are a sturdy block perfect for defending your base against most mobs. It's also an essential item for steam machines, which is probably why you'd make them.

Bronze is a pretty good material, might be a good idea to mine with it.

Bronze tools are the final step towards getting iron, they can harvest many more resources and are much faster than your dinky flint tools. pretty fun, amirite?

There are many sources of iron in the world, the main two being brown limonite veins and magnetite veins. With your bronze pickaxe you can now mine out both of them. Thus, you can now get IROOOOOOOOOOOON

Creosote is a handy byproduct of putting things through a coke oven, it can be used as a fuel source and as a way to make torches. You can also use to to make treated wood. Get creosote.

You just need to put the creosote in the bucket, BetterQuesting is good like that. Clay or Iron will work.

Bronze is a durable enough material to make proper tools out of, these tools in this quest will be the main ones you'll be using a lot. You also might want to consider upgrading your hammer, the stone one is pretty bad.

Personal advice? I'd wait off till Iron to do this, casting out all the bronze is kind of boring, but you can do it right now.

Wood is a pretty flimsy resource, why don't we treat it?

Treated wood allows for easier crafting of wooden items, like crafting tables, and the crafting of completely new items, like chests. It's a pretty neat resource isn't it?

Despite what the recipe says, you can use clay buckets for this as well.

With all of your newfangled tools, chests are now a definite possibility to make. They're a bit expensive, but it will be so, so worth it.

This quest is a crafting task, which means you can't just pick up a chest you got previously.

Finite water got you down? Don't fret! Infinite Water is here to save you! The water tank from railcraft generates a very tiny amount of water per tick, but it'll probably be enough to sustain you, at least for now.

The Slimeball can be gotten through either Tinkers Construct Slime Islands or Rice Slimeballs.

Note, unlike the 1.7.10 version, the 1.12.2 tank does not have a GUI, but it does still output water. So while it does generate water you can't see it do it in action.
Some Materials can only be mined with iron mining level or higher, thus you'll need iron tools

Redstone is a very essential wiring component, it is conductive and highly tensile... I'm just kidding! but it is required for many components required for further machines.

Redstone ore takes iron tools to mine, which you then can break with a hammer in world to get crushed redstone ore, crush it further with a hammer in a crafting grid and you get impure redstone dust. You can then throw it into a cauldron in order to obtain the actual redstone dust.

I mean, can it really be considered ore washing?

The cauldron allows for different dusts to be washed through it, this is required to get redstone, since mining it just yields the ore rather than any dust.

The Pam's Well is an infinite source of water, well isn't that just perfect! Unfortunately, water cannot be pumped out of it, it must be manually extracted with buckets. While this may substitute you for a small while, it will not work in late steam or LV, however it's still good for any crafting recipes requiring water.

Also of note, only iron buckets can pull water out of these. They're finicky, I know.

Those fancy borders around the quests actually mean something! A quest with a more rounded border is optional, and is mostly a recommendation on what to do, a quest with a kind of royal border is required to progress. Some quests are REALLY recommended even though they aren't technically required, these will just have a crowned border

Rounded Border = Optional, but recommended
Crowned Border = Necessary / Really recommended

§mdid you get the pun for this quest its icon is royal jelly, hah get it

Some alloys are just too complicated to be made in a tinkers smeltery, those alloys are basically every single one. Thus, you need alloy smelters to do the job. The steam alloy smelter can do any ULV tier (8 EU/tick) recipe for the alloy smelter. (This is true of all steam machines) This can be used to make bronze more efficiently and without pouring it out, or to make different, more complex alloys.

Red Alloy is a versatile early game resource, it is an alloy of four redstone and one copper and is used in some very early electronics. This item is most important for pistons, which we will see very shortly.

Aside from the six you made in the last quest, you will also need wire cutters. These can be used to (who guessed) cut plates into wires. You'll end up using these a lot later, but for now you just kind of need them.

Coke Ovens are painfully slow, and while you could just make more of them that'll produce way more creosote than you can reasonably handle, maybe lets try another way?

Forestry Charcoal Pits allow for mass production of charcoal, by making wood piles and encasing them in a solid square and then surrounding that on all of its open sides by some sort of block, you can go and start mass producing charcoal!

For now you only have access to three types of encasing blocks, Bricks, Coke Oven Bricks, and Seared Bricks. Out of all of these the coke oven bricks produce the best result, being a 1 to 1 ratio. You can see the amount of charcoal you get in JEI (If you minus the amount by 9, that is). Later on you can make ash bricks, and if you're really dedicated you can make Loam or Blast Furnace Bricks. But these structures should supply you for now.

The byproduct produced by these is Forestry ash, which unfortunately cannot be changed, so all Forestry ash can be crafted into GT ash, which can be used in recipes.

Despite how amazing these may seem, they can't be automated, so if you're sticking with steam you'll have to retire these at some point.

§cIMPORTANT! This has been mentioned previously but the amount in JEI that you see is NOT the amount rewarded by each block, however it is if you minus 9 from it. These structures can be effectively any sized cube you want. THe quest ONLY asks you make a wood pile. It does not matter what you encase it in.

Pushing things has never been so exhilirating!

Pistons are required for every single steam machine beyond this, so you're going to have to get them at one point or another. They aren't terrible to craft, only really taking two iron screws and red alloy, but these are an essential first component.
The Steam Furnace is a tad more efficient than a regular furnace, not like you'd know what that is. Regardless it could be nice to have depending on how much you hate your Seared Furnace.
The Steam Compressor is a very handy item, for one it now allows you to make blocks of metals, and for another... Well we'll see what else it does soon. Regardless, make it. Now.

betterquesting:10.name:8: The "Please don't use this to double your iron" Machine
betterquesting:10.desc:8:
The Steam Macerator allows you to macerate things with steam, surprisingly. These range from ores to just general blocks, and it has more utility than the regular mortars! Unfortunately, this machine is slow. Very Slow. At least with ores you're probably fine macerating clay. Anyways, only use this for doubling ores when they are very valuable

Diamonds can be found in Graphite veins, which are very low down. If you haven't found them already.
For rubber, you're going to need to extract rubber pulp out of some sticky resin. We'll explain how to get sticky resin later, but you will need an extractor later

Do you have armor? Would you like to keep that armor? Well good news for you you can now make an anvil! Since the casting basin has been disabled, your only choice to make iron blocks is through a compressor, and you'll need a few of those to make an anvil. It's expensive but oh so worth it.

The Steam Forge Hammer is an amazing item, it allows you to turn 3 ingots into 2 plates, how amazing! It may not seem like a significant change, but it starts to add up over time. It's very much recommended you make this machine, especially when doing piping.

The steam mixer can be used to mix things. You can use it this early on to make things like dough more efficiently so if you're a big foodie, it's recommended to make this. It's also required for making concrete later on.

Maybe GT Small Steam Coal Boilers dont suit your fancy? Maybe not even all the other boilers can satisfy your need for steam. We're gonna have to go bigger

The Railcraft Boilers act very similar to GT Boilers, they both take time and heat to prduce steam, however, Railcraft boilers only output steam when over 50% of their internal buffer is full, meaning they won't instantly heat up and produce steam, and also they require some form of pressure tank above. Without any steel you can only make the Solid Fueled Boiler and the Low Pressure tank. You can make these bigger, however this quest shows the minimum possible for a railcraft boiler.

The boilers will form a multiblock and output from the tank on top. Water must be imported on the boiler section.

Modular machinery is a mod that allows you to build some important multiblocks, and some quality of life multiblocks. When it's not necessary it's recommended to make these machines. Your first goal should be to make casings, which are required for all of the machines.
Every modular machine needs a machine controller, therefore you need to worry about those when making these machines. They don't take too much, however.
Every structure in Modular Machinery is in this quest tab, it might seem overwhelming but they'll only open up when you can make them.

Wrought Iron is a more durable version of Iron that can be used for tools, and is required for high pressure steam machines and steel (More on both of those later). However, making Wrought Iron isn't as simple as just smelting iron, oh no. In order to make wrought iron you need to put iron (And some sort of fuel) through a bloomery, which will be your first multiblock.

The Bloomerys' bottom floor can have either machine casing, input/output hatches or bricks. The intended idea is to use bricks as the bottom floor except for the other necessary components, though you could make it have 5 output hatches, not sure why you'd want that.

All machines other than the bloomery require a blueprint to run, not the bloomery. The bloomery can be made and ran without any blueprint of any sort.

You can speed up the bloomery as well, inserting an external heater into the middle of the structure will get it to run twice as fast.
Calcite is a material found in lazurite veins sporadically, and can only be mined with Wrought Iron level pickaxes or above. Can be used to make concrete.
Some ores can only be mined with pickaxes wrought iron level or above, so you're going to have to upgrade your pick once again.
Gypsum is a material that found in Basaltic Mineral Sand veins sporadically, it is used to make Firebricks. It can only be mined with a Wrought Iron Mining Level or above.

Liquid Concrete is a mix of Calcite dust, stone dust, sand dust, clay dust, and water. While it can't be used to make concrete at a 4 to 1 ratio, it's still able to be made, it is also used for firebricks. 

Of note is that it doesn't produce a full bucket amount of concrete, however you can just bucket it up with a wooden tank which you can get after a macerator, this will allow for far less hassle when transferring liquids between inventorys.

Currently, your only real form of fluid storage is buckets, but after some time those become basically idiotic to handle, so you're gonna want some tanks. But wait! You may say, "Didn't I already get a new fancy tank?", and yes, you can make an iron tank, but lets say you don't want such big storage, well then the GT tanks are for you.

You can only make the wood tank for now, but 4 buckets should be enough storage for your inventory handling.

Oh yeah! I should mention why these are good, it's because they can carry fluids in and out of inventorys in none-full bucket amounts. This makes them useful for fluid crafting without whole number outputs, like with concrete.

If you want to store steam to get a backlog you're gonna need something better than some flimsy tanks and drums, you'll be needing something way better than that. There are currently two options for getting massive storage of liquids, those being the Railcraft Iron Tank and the Tinkers Tank. They both can assuredly store your steam or creosote supplies, it's purely a matter of preference. The Tinker's Tank takes much less materials (mostly just a lot of seared bricks), but the Iron Tank stores 4x as much liquid per square block compared to the Tinkers Tank. 

Additionally, the Iron Tank can auto-output to GT pipes with a valve placed on the bottom middle, which the Tinkers Tank can't do, thus, if you are using the Tinker's Tank, you can't use GT pipes and must use Fluiducts or Mekanism Pipes. The Iron Tank needs the gauges to be in the center front two blocks, while everything else is iron tank walls and valves, the valves being the input and output for the liquid.

The Tinker Tank needs to have liquids inputted through the drains and the tank controller in the bottom-front center. Besides that it's basically still just a square. You dont need seared glass to complete the multiblock but it's cheap and looks nice so why not? The center for both of these tanks are hollow except for the top and bottom. Reminder that this tank can't be outputted from automatically with GT pipes (it can be inputted into, however).

The quest allows for either of these tanks to be built to complete it. The Iron Tank must at minimum be built as a 3x3x4 (Length x Width x Height) structure, while the Tinkers Tank can be at minimum a 3x3x3. This quest also shows the requirements for two tanks both of the size 3x3x4.
Can only be made by putting Wrought Iron in a Primitive Blast Furnace.

Steel is the next biggest advancement you'll be coming up on.

Steel needs to be made in the Primitive Blast Furnace, and is used for... everything? You need a lot of steel going onwards. Unfortunately, the PBF needs a lot of materials to make, and will be a major investment. But, this quest will show you what you need.

There's not many important things to note about the crafting process, you macerate, you compress, you smelt. The firebricks are fairly simple. The only really complicated thing may be the concrete, since the mixer recipe doesn't come out in whole-number amounts. This quest shows the §cMINIMUM §famount of calcite, and stone, and such needed. Make sure to complete one step and then move on to the next, since otherwise betterquesting gets messed up and will not count it.

The PBF is a 3x3x4 multiblock, that has an empty column in the middle except for the bottom block, this means that the top center block is exposed to air, or just in general isn't a firebrick. The PBF item goes into the front-middle of the second layer. If you get confused just check the item description in JEI.

High Pressure steam machines run much faster than the default steam machines, so if you don't want to rush into LV, you should make these. Regardless this quest only asks for the casing and hull for the machines, there are no individual quests for the high pressure steam machines. Anything taking these machines is just run off from this quest

Advanced Alloy is a compressed version of a possible blend of many different plates. Though the easiest to do right now would be with tin, iron, and bronze. It's a component for advanced glass and some higher tier machines.

The most powerful oven since 1982

The steam oven is a large multiblock that smelts 8 items at a time at the cost of (who'd guess it) steam. The oven is a structure with a 3x3 base, a 3x3 middle with a hollow center, and a 3x1 set of casings at the top. If you need any help building it look at the structure preview in JEI.

For both steam multiblocks you need steam buses and a steam hatch. The steam buses are fairly simple, while the steam hatch just takes some bronze and a tank. This quest shows all the materials you need for it. Of note is that the steam hatch must go on the bottom layer and the steam buses must go in the middle layer.

With this you are now a proper smelter!
Welcome to GTOW! This chapter will hopefully get you through the basics of the starting points to the pack
Nikola Tesla got NOTHING on these bad bois

Only a fool would build such powerful machines, or would they?

This is your multiblock questline. Filled with the biggest and most powerful machines you can ever make. Most quests here will be in the main line, however.
The beginning of magic! Wholely import to any master of the elements.
